title: Binders and materials made therewith
abstract: A curable aqueous composition is disclosed comprising a carbohydrate, a crosslinking agent, and an amine base, wherein the curable aqueous composition has a pH adjusted by the amine base. Further disclosed is a method of forming a curable aqueous solution.
function: What is the essential function of the product or process?

The essential function is to create a thermal or acoustical fiberglass insulation product with a formaldehyde-free, water-resistant, thermoset binder matrix that attaches glass fibers together, providing desired insulation properties.
operation: How does the product or process operate?

The product or process operates by spraying an uncured aqueous binder solution, containing Maillard reactants (amine and carbohydrate reactants), onto a mat of glass fibers. Residual heat and airflow evaporate water, curing the binder through a Maillard reaction, forming a formaldehyde-free, water-resistant, thermoset binder matrix that attaches the glass fibers together.
results: What results does this product or process achieve?

The product or process achieves a thermal or acoustical fiberglass insulation product with glass fibers bound together by a formaldehyde-free, water-resistant, thermoset binder matrix. This matrix is created through a Maillard reaction between an amine reactant and a carbohydrate reactant, resulting in nitrogen-containing polymers that attach the glass fibers. alternatives: What ingredients, materials, or processes are alternatives that can work in the same way?

Alternative ingredients may include different amine reactants (e.g., proteins, peptides, amino acids), carbohydrate reactants (e.g., monosaccharides, disaccharides, polysaccharides), organic acids, silicon-containing coupling agents, and corrosion inhibitors. The process can also be adapted by using various curing oven temperatures and times.
